definition: Central Processing Unit, the brain of a computer, executing instructions from programs
Random Access Memory, temporary storage for data actively used by the CPU
The main circuit board, connecting all computer components, e.g., CPU, RAM, and ports
Graphics Processing Unit, a specialized processor for rendering images and videos
A device for long-term data storage, using spinning magnetic disks, e.g., HDD
Solid State Drive, a fast storage device using flash memory, no moving parts
A component converting AC power to DC for computer components
Read-Only Memory, non-volatile memory storing firmware or BIOS
A communication system transferring data between computer components, e.g., data bus
High-speed memory storing frequently accessed data for quick CPU access
An input device for typing text and commands into a computer
An input device for navigating and interacting with a graphical user interface
An output device displaying visual output from a computer, e.g., LCD or LED screens
An output device producing physical copies of digital documents or images
A hardware component preventing overheating by circulating air over components
A circuit board adding functionality, e.g., graphics or sound cards
An interface connecting external devices, e.g., USB, HDMI, or Ethernet ports
Basic Input/Output System, firmware initializing hardware during computer startup
The rate at which a CPU executes instructions, measured in GHz, e.g., 3.5 GHz
A set of integrated circuits managing data flow between CPU, memory, and peripherals
Software managing hardware and software resources, e.g., Windows, Linux, macOS
The core of an operating system, handling communication between hardware and software
A method for organizing and storing files, e.g., NTFS, FAT32, or ext4
A program in execution, managed by the operating system, e.g., running a web browser
A smaller unit of a process, allowing parallel tasks within a program
An OS feature running multiple programs simultaneously, e.g., browsing and editing
A technique using hard drive space as temporary RAM to extend memory capacity
Software enabling communication between the OS and hardware, e.g., printer drivers
The means by which users interact with an OS, e.g., GUI or command line
A text-based interface for entering OS commands, e.g., Terminal or CMD
Graphical User Interface, allowing interaction via icons, windows, and menus
A request from a program to the OS for services, e.g., file access or memory allocation
A tool displaying running processes, performance, and resource usage in an OS
The sequence of steps an OS follows to start a computer, loading from BIOS to desktop
A program providing an interface to the OS, e.g., Bash for Linux or PowerShell
Fast, volatile memory directly accessible by the CPU, e.g., RAM or cache
Non-volatile storage for long-term data, e.g., hard drives or SSDs
Non-volatile memory used in USB drives and SSDs, retaining data without power
Remote storage accessed via the internet, e.g., Google Drive, Dropbox
Redundant Array of Independent Disks, combining multiple drives for redundancy or speed
A division of a storage device, treated as a separate unit by the OS, e.g., C: drive
A structure for storing data, e.g., JPEG for images, MP3 for audio
The smallest unit of digital data, either 0 or 1
A group of 8 bits, representing a single character, e.g., 'A'
A unit of storage equal to 1 trillion bytes, used for large drives
A copy of data stored separately to prevent loss, e.g., external drive or cloud
Securing data by converting it into a coded format, e.g., AES for files
Reducing file size for storage or transfer, e.g., ZIP or MP4 formats
Network Attached Storage, a device providing centralized storage over a network
A storage medium using lasers, e.g., CD, DVD, or Blu-ray for data
